datafield.subfield: Unrestricted, for either reading room or classroom use, but coach user: fragile, use care in handling.

Contents include:1. pp. 1-140: Treatise of fforest Law. What doth make a fforrest, and who may make a fforrest, and howe a fforrest is made, what things are incydent to a fforest, who may haue a fforrest, what difference is betweene a fforrest, chase, warren and Parke.2. pp. 141-146: forest-related excerpts from the Libro rubro de saccario (Red book of the Exchequer).

Includes two notes in pencil written by Thomas Fitzroy Fenwick. On front pastedown: From p. 65 to the end is Peter Le Neve's Autog (Le Neve was a 17th-century Norfolk antiquary). Below the O 17 pressmark and title on the second flyleaf, Fenwick has written This is autog. of Anstis, Garter. TFF, presumably intending the antiquary John Anstis (1669-1744), who was appointed Garter King of Arms in 1714, but the first half of the treatise is not by the same hand. Paper dated by Eric Poole (1981) to the 1630s, based on watermarks similar to Tromonin nos. 1122, 1177, and Heawood 3528.

MS 3327, Container 112: John Topham (1746-1803), Esq. FRS & AS, possibly acquired in 1787, date in pencil inside front cover on his heraldic bookplate; Sir Thomas Phillipps (1792-1872), his spine label lacking, and no indication of no. inside, but it was later sold by his grandson, Thomas Fitzroy Fenwick (1856-1938), Thirlestane House, Cheltenham, who initialled the rear flyleaf TFF X 1893; possibly sold at Sotheby's, London on 21 March 1895 as lot 714; also on inside front cover is an unidentified small square coat of arms with motto victoria concordia crescit supported by two waterbirds; later owned by Vernon James Watney (1860-1928) of Cornbury Hall, Cornwall, his oval gilt green leather bookplate on front pastedown; acquired by the Ransom Center (R5374) in 1973 from Jenkins and Company. Binding: Half-bound in brown tanned calfskin with marbled paper sides over pasteboards.
Medieval and Early Modern Manuscripts Collection.
